Lack of credible evidence: The expert's verdict highlights that there is no credible evidence to suggest that the quote attributed to President Trump's mother is real. The post provides no details or citations as to when or where the statement was made, and a search of news archives turns up no trace of it. Other fact-checking websites have also been unable to locate the statement outside of social media.
Inconsistency with news cycle: The expert points out that if Mary Anne Trump had made such an inflammatory statement about her son, it would have likely come up in the news cycle during his 2016 presidential campaign. The fact that there is no record or mention of this quote during that time adds to the skepticism regarding its authenticity.
Lack of source credibility: The post in question is flagged as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misinformation. The expert's verdict mentions that their only agenda is to publish the truth, implying that the claim being spread on social media lacks credibility and should be approached with skepticism.
Non: existence outside of social media: The expert's verdict states that the quote attributed to President Trump's mother only appears to exist in the form of memes and social media posts. It cannot be found in any interviews or books, and fact-checking websites have been unable to locate the statement. This further raises doubts about the authenticity of the claim.
